content.text: MySQL UNION Operator
The MySQL UNION Operator
The UNION operator is used to combine the result-set of two or more SELECT statements.
content.html: The UNION operator is used to combine the result-set of two or more SELECT statements.

content.text: UNION Syntax

content.code_html:
SELECT column_name(s) FROM table1
UNION
SELECT column_name(s) FROM table2;

content.text: UNION ALL Syntax
The UNION operator selects only distinct values by default. To allow duplicate values, use UNION ALL :
content.html: The UNION operator selects only distinct values by default. To allow duplicate values, use UNION ALL:

content.code_html:
SELECT column_name(s) FROM table1
UNION ALL
SELECT column_name(s) FROM table2;

content.text: Note: The column names in the result-set are usually equal to the column names in the first SELECT statement.
content.html: Note: The column names in the result-set are usually equal to the column names in the first SELECT statement.

content.text: Demo Database
In this tutorial we will use the well-known Northwind sample database.
content.html: In this tutorial we will use the well-known Northwind sample database.

content.text: Below is a selection from the "Customers" table:
content.html: Below is a selection from the "Customers" table:

content.code_html:
CustomerID CustomerName ContactName Address City PostalCode Country
1

 Alfreds Futterkiste Maria Anders Obere Str. 57 Berlin 12209 Germany
2 Ana Trujillo Emparedados y helados Ana Trujillo Avda. de la Constitución 2222 México D.F. 05021 Mexico
3 Antonio Moreno Taquería Antonio Moreno Mataderos 2312 México D.F. 05023 Mexico

content.text: And a selection from the "Suppliers" table:

content.code_html:
SupplierID SupplierName ContactName Address City PostalCode Country

2 New Orleans Cajun Delights Shelley Burke P.O. Box 78934 New Orleans 70117 USA
3 Grandma Kelly's Homestead Regina Murphy 707 Oxford Rd. Ann Arbor 48104 USA

content.text: SQL UNION Example
The following SQL statement returns the cities (only distinct values) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:
content.html: The following SQL statement returns the cities (only distinct values) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:

syntaxHighlighting.text: SELECT City FROM CustomersUNIONSELECT City FROM SuppliersORDER BY City;

content.code: SELECT City FROM CustomersUNIONSELECT City FROM SuppliersORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting.text: SELECT City FROM CustomersUNIONSELECT City FROM SuppliersORDER BY City;

content.code_html:
SELECT City FROM Customers
UNION
SELECT City FROM Suppliers
ORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting_data.text: SELECT City FROM CustomersUNIONSELECT City FROM SuppliersORDER BY City;

content.text: Note: If some customers or suppliers have the same city, each city will only be listed once, because UNION selects only distinct values. Use UNION ALL to also select duplicate values!
content.html: Note: If some customers or suppliers have the same city, each city will only be listed once, because UNION selects only distinct values. Use UNION ALL to also select duplicate values!

content.text: SQL UNION ALL Example
The following SQL statement returns the cities (duplicate values also) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:
content.html: The following SQL statement returns the cities (duplicate values also) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT City FROM CustomersUNION ALLSELECT City FROM Suppliers
 ORDER BY City;

content.code:
SELECT City FROM CustomersUNION ALLSELECT City FROM Suppliers
ORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT City FROM CustomersUNION ALLSELECT City FROM Suppliers
 ORDER BY City;

content.code_html:
SELECT City FROM Customers
UNION ALL
SELECT City FROM Suppliers
ORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT City FROM CustomersUNION ALLSELECT City FROM Suppliers
 ORDER BY City;

content.text: SQL UNION With WHERE
The following SQL statement returns the German cities (only distinct values) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:
content.html: The following SQL statement returns the German cities (only distinct values) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION
 SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

content.code:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION
SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION
 SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

content.code_html:
SELECT City, Country FROM Customers
WHERE Country='Germany'
UNION
SELECT City, Country FROM Suppliers
WHERE Country='Germany'
ORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION
 SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

content.text: SQL UNION ALL With WHERE
The following SQL statement returns the German cities (duplicate values also) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:
content.html: The following SQL statement returns the German cities (duplicate values also) from both the "Customers" and the "Suppliers" table:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION ALL
 SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

content.code:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION ALL
SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION ALL
 SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

content.code_html:
SELECT City, Country FROM Customers
WHERE Country='Germany'
UNION ALL
SELECT City, Country FROM Suppliers
WHERE Country='Germany'
ORDER BY City;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT City, Country FROM CustomersWHERE Country='Germany'UNION ALL
 SELECT City, Country FROM SuppliersWHERE Country='Germany'ORDER BY City;

content.text: Another UNION Example
The following SQL statement lists all customers and suppliers:
content.html: The following SQL statement lists all customers and suppliers:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
SELECT 'Customer' AS Type, ContactName, City, CountryFROM Customers
  UNIONSELECT 'Supplier', ContactName, City, CountryFROM Suppliers;

content.code:
SELECT 'Customer' AS Type, ContactName, City, CountryFROM Customers
UNIONSELECT 'Supplier', ContactName, City, CountryFROM Suppliers;

syntax_highlighting.text:
SELECT 'Customer' AS Type, ContactName, City, CountryFROM Customers
 UNIONSELECT 'Supplier', ContactName, City, CountryFROM Suppliers;

content.code_html:
SELECT 'Customer' AS Type, ContactName, City, Country
FROM Customers
UNION
SELECT 'Supplier', ContactName, City, Country
FROM Suppliers;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
SELECT 'Customer' AS Type, ContactName, City, CountryFROM Customers
  UNIONSELECT 'Supplier', ContactName, City, CountryFROM Suppliers;

content.text: Notice the "AS Type" above - it is an alias. SQL Aliases are used to give a table or a column a temporary name. An alias only exists for the duration of the query. So, here we have created a temporary column named "Type", that list whether the contact person is a "Customer" or a "Supplier".
content.html: Notice the "AS Type" above - it is an alias. SQL Aliases are used to give a table or a column a temporary name. An alias only exists for the duration of the query. So, here we have created a temporary column named "Type", that list whether the contact person is a "Customer" or a "Supplier".
